report:
======================================================================
CORRELATION VS. CAUSATION ANALYSIS REPORT
======================================================================

⚠️  FUNDAMENTAL PRINCIPLE ⚠️
----------------------------------------------------------------------
CORRELATION ≠ CAUSATION

Just because two systems appear related does NOT mean:
• One causes the other
• They should be linked in the architecture
• Changes in one will affect the other

However, observed correlations ARE worth exploring scientifically
to determine if actual causal relationships exist.
======================================================================

OBSERVED CORRELATIONS: 3
----------------------------------------------------------------------

1. Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System ↔ Deer Population System (Unchecked)
   Pattern: Both use unknown framework - may indicate similar behavioral patterns
   Strength: 60%
   Observed by: system
   Evidence:
     • Both use unknown framework
     • Similar frameworks often indicate related behaviors

2. Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System ↔ Vegetation Ecosystem System
   Pattern: Both use unknown framework - may indicate similar behavioral patterns
   Strength: 60%
   Observed by: system
   Evidence:
     • Both use unknown framework
     • Similar frameworks often indicate related behaviors

3. Deer Population System (Unchecked) ↔ Vegetation Ecosystem System
   Pattern: Both use unknown framework - may indicate similar behavioral patterns
   Strength: 60%
   Observed by: system
   Evidence:
     • Both use unknown framework
     • Similar frameworks often indicate related behaviors


CAUSAL HYPOTHESES: 12
----------------------------------------------------------------------
These are PROPOSED causal relationships that require validation.


1. Hypothesis: a_causes_b
   Changes in Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System cause corresponding changes in Deer Population System (Unchecked)
   Confidence: 40%
   Proposed Mechanism: Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System produces outputs/events that Deer Population System (Unchecked) consumes/responds to
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Reverse causation (other direction)
     • Bidirectional causation (both affect each other)
     • Confounding variable (both affected by third factor)
     • Spurious correlation (coincidental)

2. Hypothesis: b_causes_a
   Changes in Deer Population System (Unchecked) cause corresponding changes in Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System
   Confidence: 40%
   Proposed Mechanism: Deer Population System (Unchecked) produces outputs/events that Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System consumes/responds to
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Reverse causation (other direction)
     • Bidirectional causation (both affect each other)
     • Confounding variable (both affected by third factor)
     • Spurious correlation (coincidental)

3. Hypothesis: bidirectional
   Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System and Deer Population System (Unchecked) form a feedback loop where each affects the other
   Confidence: 30%
   Proposed Mechanism: Bidirectional coupling with feedback: changes in either system propagate to the other
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Unidirectional causation (only one direction)
     • Independent systems with shared confounding factor
     • Spurious correlation

4. Hypothesis: no_causation
   Correlation between Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System and Deer Population System (Unchecked) is spurious - no causal mechanism
   Confidence: 30%
   Proposed Mechanism: No causal mechanism. Systems may be correlated due to: shared external factor, coincidental timing, or selection bias
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Hidden causal mechanism not yet discovered
     • Indirect causation through intermediate system
     • Confounding variable causing both

5. Hypothesis: a_causes_b
   Changes in Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System cause corresponding changes in Vegetation Ecosystem System
   Confidence: 40%
   Proposed Mechanism: Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System produces outputs/events that Vegetation Ecosystem System consumes/responds to
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Reverse causation (other direction)
     • Bidirectional causation (both affect each other)
     • Confounding variable (both affected by third factor)
     • Spurious correlation (coincidental)

6. Hypothesis: b_causes_a
   Changes in Vegetation Ecosystem System cause corresponding changes in Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System
   Confidence: 40%
   Proposed Mechanism: Vegetation Ecosystem System produces outputs/events that Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System consumes/responds to
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Reverse causation (other direction)
     • Bidirectional causation (both affect each other)
     • Confounding variable (both affected by third factor)
     • Spurious correlation (coincidental)

7. Hypothesis: bidirectional
   Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System and Vegetation Ecosystem System form a feedback loop where each affects the other
   Confidence: 30%
   Proposed Mechanism: Bidirectional coupling with feedback: changes in either system propagate to the other
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Unidirectional causation (only one direction)
     • Independent systems with shared confounding factor
     • Spurious correlation

8. Hypothesis: no_causation
   Correlation between Beaver Ecosystem Engineering System and Vegetation Ecosystem System is spurious - no causal mechanism
   Confidence: 30%
   Proposed Mechanism: No causal mechanism. Systems may be correlated due to: shared external factor, coincidental timing, or selection bias
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Hidden causal mechanism not yet discovered
     • Indirect causation through intermediate system
     • Confounding variable causing both

9. Hypothesis: a_causes_b
   Changes in Deer Population System (Unchecked) cause corresponding changes in Vegetation Ecosystem System
   Confidence: 40%
   Proposed Mechanism: Deer Population System (Unchecked) produces outputs/events that Vegetation Ecosystem System consumes/responds to
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Reverse causation (other direction)
     • Bidirectional causation (both affect each other)
     • Confounding variable (both affected by third factor)
     • Spurious correlation (coincidental)

10. Hypothesis: b_causes_a
   Changes in Vegetation Ecosystem System cause corresponding changes in Deer Population System (Unchecked)
   Confidence: 40%
   Proposed Mechanism: Vegetation Ecosystem System produces outputs/events that Deer Population System (Unchecked) consumes/responds to
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Reverse causation (other direction)
     • Bidirectional causation (both affect each other)
     • Confounding variable (both affected by third factor)
     • Spurious correlation (coincidental)

11. Hypothesis: bidirectional
   Deer Population System (Unchecked) and Vegetation Ecosystem System form a feedback loop where each affects the other
   Confidence: 30%
   Proposed Mechanism: Bidirectional coupling with feedback: changes in either system propagate to the other
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Unidirectional causation (only one direction)
     • Independent systems with shared confounding factor
     • Spurious correlation

12. Hypothesis: no_causation
   Correlation between Deer Population System (Unchecked) and Vegetation Ecosystem System is spurious - no causal mechanism
   Confidence: 30%
   Proposed Mechanism: No causal mechanism. Systems may be correlated due to: shared external factor, coincidental timing, or selection bias
   Validation Status: untested
   Alternative Explanations:
     • Hidden causal mechanism not yet discovered
     • Indirect causation through intermediate system
     • Confounding variable causing both


======================================================================
RECOMMENDED NEXT STEPS
======================================================================
1. Review all correlations and hypotheses
2. Select hypotheses to test based on:
   • Importance to system integration
   • Ease of validation
   • User confidence in the relationship
3. Design validation experiments (see validation plans)
4. Execute validation studies
5. Update relationship status based on evidence
6. Only link architectures based on VALIDATED causal relationships

⚠️  CRITICAL: Do not assume causation from correlation alone!
